column1: How many acres will be consumed by reported wildfires in the US in 2022?
column5: ['Fewer than 6.5 million', 'Between 6.5 million and 8.0 million, inclusive', 'More than 8.0 million but fewer than 9.5 million', 'Between 9.5 million and 11.0 million, inclusive', 'More than 11.0 million but fewer than 12.5 million', '12.5 million or more']
column6: ['Environment']
With rain and storms hitting, I'm dropping to 0% that we'll have 500k+ acres of fires in the next 5 days

Not sure why the data on the website has gone two weeks stale, but https://fsapps.nwcg.gov/ seems to confirm there aren't any big fires. 750k acres in 27 days feels all-but-impossible, but I'm going to stick with 1% here as there are still lots of dry parts of the country and a low fire season means lots of combustable material is still out there.
Thanks @probahilliby
Thanks @probahilliby that found the updated data in the PDF

@404_NOT_FOUND @lbiii @tabhuth @m_collier The website here {https://www.nifc.gov/fire-information/nfn} is still 17-day old Nov 11 data, no? But if you click the hyperlink on that page that says "Please check the IMSR for more information," you will see this PDF with more recent data: https://www.nifc.gov/nicc/sitreprt.pdf
Based on most recent Fire data, I am projecting out a final EOY estimate of ~7.5 (+/-) 0.17 M Acres burned.

~13.5k acre/day avg. burn rate since the day the Question opened. Rounding up, ~1k acre/day avg. burn rate over the last 3 weeks, although the ‚Äúinstantaneous‚Äù burn rate is very difficult to estimate with any precision now because of the lower updating frequency.
Almost no active fires and the total is stalling around 7.25M

Despite the past week's acres burned per fire being 214% above the latest 3-year average, it seems that the past 5 years to data (up to 11/14 in any given year), about 91% of all acres burned that occurred that year have already burned, meaning that by the end of the year 2022, there should be 7,983,519.36 acres burned. That's one way to look at this.
9.4 million
West coast precipitation: the Ananas Express.

Down to only 127k acres of active fires and stalling around 7.22M. Rain is hitting the west. This one seems all but decided unless a very hot and dry spell hits the west or a big fire starts somewhere unexpected.
bumping C a bit for some hedge...

Although I'm starting to get sub 8M estimates, the previous week's burn rate and the overall burn rate for the year still gets me above 8M. Short-term and long-term agreement. However, my forecast compared to last forecast has dipped by almost 200,000 acres, so if this trend continues, sub 8M like the crowd consensus will verify. All things considered, I'm going to say this is likely a bin 2 resolution but not as sure as crowd given my points above.
My forecast remains about the same for the EOY ~ 7.7 (+/-) 0.33 M Acres. Upping my forecast probability as the uncertainty decreases over time.

For a while, monitoring the NIFC - statistics link embedded in this Question‚Äôs ‚Äúfine print‚Äù was easy as it updated near-daily. Since ~10/27 it seems to not be getting updated (static 7,210,454 ac reported for many days now). Per the document linked below (11/4), I think the current acreage burned to-date will have grown to ~7,235,000 acres.
Aren't there still wildfires burning?

Active fires are down to 280k acres, total is 7.2, so that is a 3x multiple to clear the 8 bucket, meaning there would likely need to be a few big new fires. we have two months left and rain + snow are hitting the northwest, so the available land for this to happen is really only the southwest. Highly confident we won‚Äôt clear 8M

Switching odds based on currently active acres of 580k. To clear 8M from the current ~7 those acres would need to each expand by 3x. That seems much less likely than a few days ago when the active fires were >750k and the time has decreased as well. I think we're going to be right in the 7.5-8.5 range and so I'm straddling that line but tipping a bit more to fewer given the active fires in Washington/Oregon are getting some rain this week.

At this point, the fire rate is past the peak for the year and continues to decelerate. I'm projecting a final EOY total expected mean +/- 1 SD of 7.5M acres +/- 0.3M, based on simple OLS regression of Dec totals vs Oct totals for the last 22 years. Still hedging a little towards the upside but will adjust further as the month continues.
6,937,344 acres burned to date. ~17.3k acre/day avg. burn rate since the day the Question opened. ~4.4k acre/day avg. burn rate over last 3 weeks.

Looked at years that have hit this total by this date and while all of the years with more acres burned by this point ended up with >8M on the year, there weren't many that were that really close, most were much bigger or a bit smaller. Meanwhile there aren't many years where we've seen >1M acres in the final 2.5 months, which is what we have left.
Updating based on slowing recent numbers for October.
6.885 at the end of September.

Total is now 6.8 with a lot of fires in Washington. As we move into October we hit peak California fire season. Based on the stats right now we'll be pretty stable in the 8-9.5 bucket unless the final moths are extreme outliers.
Reran regression using today's cumulative numbers. The rate of fire spread is slowing as expected. I get a final EOY estimate of approximately 8M (+/-) 500k Acres. Am updating my bets accordingly.
6,845,993 acres burned to date. ~20.1k acre/day avg. burn rate since the day the Question opened.
Updating based on today's data and aggregating with crowd.
September rate has been around 45K acres/day, this pushes the forecast higher.

Major update after @m_collier pointed out a stupid error on my part. Redid models to exclude the nonsensical lower distribution tail (since Bin 1 is already below the current total numbers) that resulted from my use of OLS with fire damage converted to logs, as well as a bug in my extrapolation. Am now projecting Sept to have ~6.9 MAcres burned +/- 10% or so. End result is a projected final EOY forecast of 7.8M acres +/- about 7%. Obviously still plenty of time for things to change and will adjust as necessary based on new data.
Updating based on most recent fire numbers and aggregating with the crowd.
El valor promedio desde 2000 esta en los 7.0 M acres
reverting to estimates similar to original forecast
Updated based on data through 9/4/22 using an annual and monthly linear model + aggregation with the crowd.
Updating based on the 9/1/22 cumulative data.
As @m_collier pointed out, data from yesterday has been fixed.
6.1 at the end of August.

The average millions of acres that burn in the period from the start of September to te end of the year is 1.2 (data from the past 22 years). The spread around this mean is quite large as it goes from a minimum of 0.7M acres in 2001 to a maximum of 6.3M in 2020.

At over 6M acres so far. The last years to get to that point by this date in the year averaged 9.4M by the end of the year so I'm adjusting my prior up a bit. Using 9.4 number as a guide I'll put most of the weight in that bucket. There is a chance of the over. and adjusting for a decently large amount of randomness. >11M hasn't happened in the ~10 years I have data for, so assigning a very low chance to anything greater than that.
Adjusting bins based on data as of 8/27/22.
August is turning out to be a massive outlier. Am I reading the data correctly? Less than 300K acres in the first 21 days! it may set a record low.
Updating based on the 8/21 cumulative acres burned using HWinter, SARIMA, and Linear models aggregated with the crowd.
5,951,890 acres burned to date. ~14.2k acre/day avg. burn rate since the Question opened. And we‚Äôve been in peak fire season the whole time so far, expecting a decrease in this rate in fall/winter.
Updating on most recent data. Aggregating between annual OLS, monthly OLS, Holt-Winters, and a SARIMA(1,1,1) model with the crowd.
Updating with aggregations of an annual + monthly OLS model + a Holt Winters + SARIMA model.

June-August is peak for the US (Though I know from experience, southern California is more likely to have them in Sep and Oct) and we are already half way through that period. The 10 year average is 7.5, but 60% of the years are above 8.5. Now that we're already above 5 (and 3 of the last 10) it seems likely we'll get to at least that 7.5 and likely the 8.5.
Revised my forecast after aggregating 4 different models and estimating the sample standard deviation of the mean forecast. Finally, I aggregated with the crowd to obtain these results.

Just starting with this forecast. I combined the monthly data outlined by @LewisWalsh and have run a combination of OLS and SARIMA forecasts as a first approximation. I then aggregated with selected peers. There is a strong seasonal component to the monthly forecasts with the peak of the fire season between Jul and Sep. I've pasted the 10th, 90th, and Mean #fires per month from Jan through Dec below:

Updating ‚Äúreference case‚Äù calculation from previous forecast (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1485948) to account for elapsed time, and for the fact that the average burn rate since the Question opened has been substantially higher than my initial ‚Äúinstantaneous‚Äù estimate.
Kudos to @LewisWalsh for the great job.
NICC Wildland Fire Summary and Statistics annual reports.
Bravo to @LewisWalsh for some excellent legwork here. üëç
Last 20 yrs of fires as follows [1]
YTD data is probably not really accurate, but it may be a decent place to start.

Initial highly subjective forecast. Considering that there‚Äôs still much of the ‚Äúfire season‚Äù ahead of us, putting a fairly low chance on bin #1. The rate of change here is obviously going to be highly variable, depending on how many and how large any given moment‚Äôs active fires are across the country. The final cumulative count will also be correspondingly difficult to extrapolate from, e.g., simple YTD observations. As of the day that this Question opened, 5,538,851 acres have reportedly already burned.
The historical data is bimodal, either less than 6.5 million or around 9.5 million. 5.5 have already burned this year, so it is a little more likely we are in universe 2.
